awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Consequences of Environmental Stochasticity for the Spatial Dynamics of Savanna-Forest Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
Changing temperature and rainfall patterns globally will have  major effects on vegetation patterns, in some cases shifting the nature of ecosystems dramatically with consequences for wildlife, and for the services that natural systems provide to humans.  These “critical transitions”  are possible outcomes of environmental shifts in a wide variety of systems, including the savanna and forest transitions that this project will address, in which changes in frequency of fires can be especially important in changing the nature of these key ecosystem types. Building on previous work by the project leaders, this research will develop and apply state-of-the-art mathematical models, in concert with empirical studies, to predict how changing environmental conditions will mediate shifts in the savanna-forest boundary.  This project will also enhance education and training at multiple levels, including the training of a postdoctoral fellow; development of graduate and undergraduate research projects; and data visualization through collaboration with artist and educator Neil Goldberg.

The potential for multiple stable states, respectively forest and savanna, in vegetation systems has been previously demonstrated, combining empirical work with dynamical systems models.  The introduction of spatial effects leads to systems of partial-differential or partial differential-integral equations, including stochastic influences, which of course are more complicated to analyze, but are crucial for predicting the shifts of boundaries.  This project will develop and apply new methodologies drawn from non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, and will generate novel mathematical results, in particular in terms of fluctuations around the mean-field limit, developing new approaches to these stochastic systems, and applying a  novel landscape-flux approach. A key element will involve the training of a truly interdisciplinary postdoctoral fellow to be fluent both in the mathematical dimensions of the project and the ecological data analysis.

This award is funded jointly by the MPS Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) through the Mathematical Biology Program and BIO/DEB through the Cluster of Population and Community Ecology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most consistent predictions, supported by observations, is an increase in the variability of future climate. This is especially true of rainfall; whereas trends in mean rainfall have been challenging to predict and diverse depending on local conditions, rainfall unequivocally is becoming more variable globally. This variability poses a challenge for predicting ecological dynamics in response to future climate, necessitating a modeling approach that goes beyond deterministic models to include stochastic fluctuations and uncertainty and incorporating spatial processes. Multiple stable basins of attraction exacerbate the complexity of the problem, and characterize the ecosystems that are the focus of the research proposed here.

For leverage on this problem, we studied a system that we understand well from an ecological standpoint, that exhibits well-supported potential for alternative stable states and other complex dynamics, and where stochastic effects and spatial variation are important -- the savanna-forest system, where vegetation feedbacks with fire can maintain savannas even where forest represent the climax vegetation state. Our work has led to deeper understanding of these systems, with applications to other systems with similarly complex dynamics.
We have shown that, as a result of variable slow-time-scale processes, for example tree growth and demography, transitions from savanna to forest are not reversible and occur via different trajectories than transitions from forest to savanna; this result arises in both mathematical work as well as empirical observations of real savanna-forest system. These features create difficulties in observing transitions directly, and yet these are of great importance to ecologists and indeed to societies. We have also tackled the problem of how spatial processes influence dynamics, showing that alternately stable spatial mosaics are possible, with dynamically shifting boundaries, confounding straightforward interpretations of ongoing vegetation change. In addition to providing ecological insight, the work has generated novel mathematical results, in particular in terms of fluctuations around the mean-field limit, the connection with stochastic differential equation systems, and the novel landscape-flux approach for discovering the underlying mechanisms sustaining ecosystems. Together, our work has expanded our tool-kit for examining transient dynamics in ecological (and other) complex systems.
